RClusterCT overview

2018-06-22

Source: vignettes/overview.Rmd
overview.Rmd

Why use RClusterCT?

Simple Example

# load pacakge data
data("pbmc4k_matrix")
data("pbmc4k_meta")
data("pbmc4k_vargenes")
data("pbmc_bulk_matrix")

# run correlation 
res <- run_cor(pbmc4k_matrix,
        pbmc4k_meta,
        pbmc_bulk_matrix,
        pbmc4k_vargenes,
        if_permute = F,
        compute_method = corr_coef)

res[1:10, 1:10]

Plot cluster identities and correlation coefficients

# plot tsne using known identities
plot_tsne(pbmc4k_meta, feature = "classified")


# plot correlation coefficients on tsne for each identity class
plot_cor(res,
         pbmc4k_meta,
         colnames(res)[1:7])
#> Warning: package 'bindrcpp' was built under R version 3.4.4

Obtain p-value for similarity using a permutation test

We can also calcualte correlation p-values using permutation with the run_cor() function.

res <- run_cor(pbmc4k_matrix,
               pbmc4k_meta,
               pbmc_bulk_matrix,
                pbmc4k_vargenes,
               if_permute = TRUE,
               num_permute=1000,
               metadata = "classified",
               compute_method = corr_coef,
               return_full = TRUE)

res$p_val[1:10, 1:10]
#>                     primary human B cells rep 1
